subsection.title: The Natural Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: Recall that each exponential function with base b has an inverse function, the logarithmic function with the same base. For example, the function ~y=\log_2{(x)}~ is the inverse of the function ~y=2^x. It gives the exponent needed on 2 to give x, so that, for instance, ~\log_2{(16)} = 4~, because ~2^4 = 16.

The base e logarithm of a number x, or \log_ e x, is called the natural logarithmnatural logarithm of x and is denoted by \ln x. (Why ln and not nl? The natural logarithm is denoted by ln because it stands for logarithmus naturalis, which is the Latin for natural logarithm.) Here is its official definition.

assemblage.title: The Natural Logarithm
assemblage.p: The natural logarithm is the logarithm base e. \ln x = \log_{e}{x}, ~~~~ x\gt 0

subsection.p: The natural logarithm of x is the exponent to which e must be raised to produce x. For example, the natural logarithm of 10, or \ln 10, is the solution of the equation e^y = 10 You can verify on your calculator that e^{\alert{2.3}} ~~ \approx 10 \text{ or } ~~ \ln 10 \approx \alert{2.3}

As is the case with exponential and log functions with other bases, the natural log functionnatural log function, y= \ln {(x)}, and the natural exponential function, f(x) = e^x, undo each other, so they are inverse functions. (This is why many calculators use 2nd LN to indicate e^x.)

image.description: graphs of ln and natural exponential

solution.p: You can see that the graph of g(x) = \ln {(x)} is the reflection of the graph of f(x) = e^x about the line y=x. In particular, notice that while the graph of f(x) = e^x has no points with negative y-values, the graph of g(x) = \ln {(x)} has no points with negative x-values. Thus, the domain of the natural log function is the same as the range of y = e^x, or all positive numbers. The range of y = \ln x is the same as the domain of y = e^x, or all real numbers.

subsection.p: From the graph of g(x) = \ln {(x)} you can make the following observations.

ul.li: The natural log function has only positive numbers as input values.
The natural logs of negative numbers and zero are undefined.
The natural log of a number greater than 1 is positive, while the logs of numbers between 0 and 1 are negative.

subsection.title: Properties of the Natural Logarithm
subsection.p: Natural logs obey the same conversion formulas that work for logs to other bases.

p.me: \blert{y = \ln x} ~~\text{ if and only if } ~~ \blert{e^y = x}

subsection.p: The conversion formulas are just another way of saying the the the natural log function, g(x) = \ln x, and the natural exponential function, f(x) = e^x, are inverse functions.
In particular, \begin{aligned}[t] \ln e \amp = 1 \text{ because } e^1 = e \\ \ln 1 \amp = 0 \text{ because } e^0 = 1 \\ \end{aligned}

subsection.title: Exponential Growth and Decay
subsection.p:
In , we considered functions of the form
P(t) = P_0\cdot b^t
which describe exponential growth when b \gt 1 and exponential decay when 0 \lt b \lt 1. Exponential growth and decay can also be modeled by functions of the form
\blert{P(t) = P_0 \cdot e^{kt}}
where we have substituted e^k for the growth factor b, so that \begin{aligned}[t] P(t) \amp = P_0 \cdot b^t\\ \amp = P_0 \cdot \left(e^k\right)^t = P_0 \cdot e^{kt}\\ \end{aligned} We can find the value of k by solving the equation b = e^k for k, to get k = \ln b.

sidebyside.p: By graphing both functions on your calculator, you can verify that P(t) = 100 \cdot 3^t ~~~\text{and}~~~ P(t) = 100 \cdot e^{1.0986t} are just two ways of writing the same function.

subsection.p: Sometimes exponential growth is given as a percentage, so for example we might say prices rose by 5% annually. In this case the growth factor is ~b=1+r~, where r is the percentage rate in decimal form. For a percent decrease, ~b=1-r~.

li.p: The growth factor was b = 1 + r = 1.064. The population t years later was P(t) = 768,000 (1.064)^t
We use the formula P(t) = P_0 \cdot e^{kt}, where e^k = 1.064. Solving for k, we find k = \ln 1.064 = 0.062 so P(t) = 768,000 e^{0.062t}.

subsection.p: Now, what about exponential decay, where the the decay factor b is a number less than 1? If k is negative, then e^k is a number less than 1. For example, if k = -2, e^{-2} = \frac{1}{e^2} \approx \frac{1}{7.3891} \approx 0.1353 Thus, for negative values of k, the function P(t) = P_0 e^{kt} describes exponential decay.

solution.p: For this decay law, N_0 = 60 and b = 0.8. We would like to find a value for k so that e^k = b = 0.8, that is, we must solve the equation \begin{aligned}[t] e^k \amp = 0.8\amp\amp \blert{\text{Take natural log of both sides.}}\\ \ln e^k\amp = \ln 0.8\amp\amp \blert{\text{Simplify.}}\\ k\amp = \ln 0.8 \approx -0.2231 \end{aligned} Replacing b with e^k, we find that the decay law is N(t) \approx 60e^{-0.2231t}

statement.p: Suppose you invest $500 in an account that pays 8\% interest compounded continuously. You leave the money in the account without making any additional deposits or withdrawals.

ol.li: Write a formula that gives the value of your account A(t) after t years.

How much will the account be worth after 10 years?
How long will it be before the account is worth $1000?
We substitute 500 for P, and 0.08 for r to find A(t) = 500e^{0.08t}

li.p: We evaluate the formula for A(t) to obtain a table.

ol.li: The graph of A(t) is shown above.
We evaluate A(t) for t = 10. \begin{aligned}[t] A(10) \amp= 500 e^{0.08(10)}\\ \amp = 500 e^{0.8}\\ \amp \approx 500(2.2255) = 1112.77 \end{aligned} The account will be worth $1112.77 after 10 years.

We substitute 1000 for A(t) and solve the equation. \begin{aligned}[t] 1000 \amp= 500 e^{0.08t}\amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 500.}}\\ 2 \amp = e^{0.08t}\amp\amp \blert{\text{Take natural log of both sides.}}\\ \ln 2 \amp= \ln e^{0.08t} = 0.08t\amp\amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by 0.08.}}\\ t \amp= \frac{\ln 2}{0.08}\approx 8.6643 \end{aligned} The account will be worth $1000 after approximately 8.7 years.
